resources.string: Send macronutrients to composing the meal
No Food.\nFood will be here after add from Food Table
No Composed Meals.\nMeals will be here after add from \"Compose The Meal\"
No custom food.\nCustom food will be here after add from Food Table > + ADD FOOD
Click the table to get information about the composition of the meal
Select the meals you want to add to the daily menu
Click the name of product to get information about his composition
No Composed Daily Meals.\nDaily Meals will be here after add from \"Composed Meals\"
Here are healthy information about food. Click on the selected item.
The caloric requirement of each person is different depending on many factors. Such as weight, height and physical activity. The calorie converter is:

The average person needs about 2,000 kcal per day. This is how much is included in the packaging of food products.\nThe demand consists of BMR (basal metabolic rate) multiplied by the value of physical activity. There are formulas to calculate BMR. The BNO uses the Mifflin-St Jeor formula.
low activity (sitting work\nand 1 - 2 workouts per week)
moderate activity (sitting work\nand 3 - 4 workouts a week)
high activity (physical work\nand 3-4 workouts a week)
very high activity\n(professional athletes, people\ntraining every day)
Carbohydrates are made up of simple and complex sugars. Complex ones are more beneficial for the body as they provide energy for longer. Simple is sugar. Complex ones are found in e.g. pasta, flour.

They are stored in small quantities, 250-321g and it is enough for 12 hours with a demand of 2000kcal. When not enough is supplied, the body uses up protein and fats. The excess is converted into fats leading to obesity.
They should provide 50-60% of the daily caloric requirement. They are necessary to maintain proper health, necessary to be active and physically fit for a long time.

They are a good source of energy, so they should be supplied to the body in the morning after waking up. They should be included in breakfast, lunch and dinner. In the morning, the body needs a dose of energy to accelerate the metabolic rate that has slowed down during the night. In the evening, it is better to avoid carbohydrates because the body will not use energy and transform the excess into adipose tissue.
Avoid empty calories such as confectionery, sweets, sugary carbonated drinks, sweet non-carbonated beverages and highly processed foods, as they do not have any valuable nutrients.
The body uses protein on an ongoing basis and does not store its reserves for another time. Excess protein is simply excreted, so make sure you get the right amount every day.
One of the most important functions is building muscle mass and regenerating muscle cells.
The demand for protein depends on many factors, including age, gender and physical activity.

The daily requirement should not be unsatisfied because it lowers the metabolism, immunity, well-being, condition of the skin, hair and nails, or exceeded it, because it overloads the liver and kidneys, increases the risk of inflammation.
children up to 15 years of age
Fats are the most caloric component of our diet. 1g = 9kcal, more than 2 times more than protein and carbohydrates. Not all fats are bad, some fats are needed for life.

They contain in saturated and unsaturated. The unsaturated are healthier. Animal fats are high in calories, cholesterol, and saturated fats that raise blood cholesterol and accelerate the development of atherosclerosis.

Saturated fat should not provide more than 10% of calories per day. It is better to avoid fat-free inventions because then we will deprive ourselves of valuable vitamins dissolved in fats: A, D, E, K.
Low levels of dietary fat may contribute to:
Water is essential for the proper functioning of the human psyche and its physical fitness. Without it, you can get headaches and a bad mood.

It is a building block of the joint space, therefore it prevents arthritis and back pain. It protects the brain, spinal cord, tissues and organs. It strengthens the production of neurotransmitters, improves memory and slows down the aging process.

Children have the highest amount of water in the body, it is 78%, and by the first year the value drops to 65%. Adult males are approximately 60% and adult females approximately 55%. The difference is that adipose tissue in women is a greater part of the body than in men, and fat contains less water than lean tissue.
Every day about 6% of body fluid is lost through sweat, 6% in stool, and 28% through skin evaporation and breathing. 60% is lost with the urine.

The water requirement can be calculated by multiplying your body weight by 0.030. It is assumed that for 1 kg of body weight, 30 milliliters of water should be provided. For 1 calorie consumed, you should take 1 milliliter of water. Therefore, for 2000 kcal, you need to consume 2000 milliliters, which is 2 liters.
It is estimated that about 60% of water is absorbed from drinks, 30% from food, and another 10% is produced as a result of metabolism.
